0C5IuFeC7sgMe_lFlvnlew.text: Let's get this right.  This isn't fine dining but for the prices they charge, it is fine dining.  It's a wonderful surprise to find a place in central London that is reasonably priced, high on service and quality.  I mean, a short stroll down into Leicester square and you're faced with the turgid Garfunkel's, the hit and miss Chinatown and all the other tourist traps that proclaim to serve traditional English fish and chips etc etc.  The restaurant is in the basement but the evenly lit, light marble and gold interior makes you think otherwise.  I wouldn't say it was subtle.Service was fantastic.  My wife and I arrived with 3 kids in tow, and a large pram.  The maitre d' ensured we had a seat that accomodated our massive US style stroller.  We were next to another young family so whether by accident or design, we were able to enjoy meal safe in the knowledge that our noise levels were hidden by the adjoining table.  As I said, the food isn't fine dining.  It's a class above chains like Cafe Rouge at Cafe Rouge prices so on that fact alone, it's a winner.  I'd like to say that the fish soup is superb - sea salty and deep in slow cooked fishiness.  The charcuterie Zedel is a mixture of porkie products on a bed of sauerkraut: Bacon, sausages, hams.  It's salty and could do with being served with bread.  It isn't so you should order it separately.  Overall recommended!

BSiR3RXKmYHjt2UhzleKhA.text: This is a fantastic place in London. The ambiance  spectacular, and there is even a jazz bar and Theatre inside. Food is superb service is impeccable. I had the steak hache withbpeppercorn sauce which was delicious for a chopped steak. The escargot was great as well. Definitely a must when you visit London !

Sk-jLPscu_5uM8H-sWZVVg.text: The perfect place for pre theatre drinks and dinner. A place for all budgets with a greatest hits of French classics. Always love going here...

Z7RdukUfkCAvqEwiCPl-lg.text: With a beautiful ambience to the entire construction, the food matches so.It's not usually my cup of tea, but definitely a place that should be tried by everyone.There aren't many affordable places that you can walk into and feel like you're a special guest at a Mary Antoinette orgy, but this place does it well - and all without the posh stigma. You're just in a nice place.The food - what a selection! Brilliantly cooked, brilliantly served.No complaints from me! :)

NOYUwYagu45yXLo22XNUOg.text: C'est super Bon! Love the food, the wine, the service and the environment, very arty and cozy, I even took a menu home, because there is a vintage drawing behind. Great French restaurant, will definitely come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Forgot the name...
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Creme brulee

0IE2KH1k86rDVZV6yIDUYQ.text: The place looks frankly, amazing. Great service and some pretty decent music after 9pm. The only problem, the food, fairly bland and nothing to write home about in the vegetarian menu. Can't say I'd recommended it.

j6kd1oL2GAFNalUjG9l9Uw.text: Absolutely positively love this restaurant.  This is one of my favourite restaurants in London, amusingly somewhat because it reminds me of my favourite places in NYC. The decor is timeless, the staff highly professional, and the food ...simply superb, especially for the price. Saunter in and feel you've been sucked back into the late 1930s. The amber lighting is warm and enticing....and looks particularly good on any complexion.  The waitstaff are immaculately dressed, and their manners...impeccable.  (cue: wow what good service) . Decor: Have a look at the photos posted, they speak for themselves. The menu is what you would expect from a brasserie, but a few notches higher on the quality scale.  I've had a few fish dishes here and my companion had the steak several times, all of which have been perfectly cooked, seasoned, and served in a generous portion every time.  From what people tell me ordering steak in London can be a bit hit or miss, but not here.Highly recommended. And visit the neighboring Bar Americain. It's a dream.

dCPtRTh_NgSuhfwA0zHt_w.text: Top marks. Brasserie Zedel delivered a fantastic dining experience. The grand dining room was buzzing when we arrived at 9pm. We were promptly seated and offered water. We dined from the menu Formula which is good value for such a central location. Our waitress was knowledgeable and helpful with our wine choices - even allowing me to try 2 wines before settling on the Pinot Noir (highly recommend!) Starter of an unfamiliar celeriac dish was nice enough however the mains of beef bourguignon with creamy mash and grilled mackerel were both delicious. Well cooked and balanced dishes. The meat was so tender! To finish we had floating islands which were beautifully presented and (though I couldn't finish mine) a lovely end to the meal. Our water and wine was topped up unobtrusively and the was no pushy table turning even though they were extremely busy. Thanks Zedal - fabulous night!

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Pre dinner cocktails!

Mly9xrkck4T3VxPiyl_uaA.text: I made a call reservation earlier but when i arrived they claimed i didn't even call! It was quite frustrating cause we then had to queue up at the bar next to the brasserie to wait for a table. We ordered a beer and a glass of Chardonnay with chips during our wait. The attitude of a particular waitress at the bar was not very nice, but the rest of the service was friendly and welcoming. The interior was indeed impressive (as described in all the other comments here) with all the art deco fit out with a mix and match of american-french visuals.. The thick chips that came along with the drinks were perfectly fried, but the presentation of them snuggling in a little cup was not as appealing as i would prefer. For dinner we ordered a Formule menu with celeriac as appetizer, beef in red wine as a main, and a floating island for dessert, accompanied with a glass of red. We also ordered the escargot and Choucroute Alsacienne, which is a nice mix of pork belly, sausage on a bed of pickled cabbage. Dinner overall was okay, the beef was a little dry and the pork wasn't remarkably good, but if you are just looking for a cosy standard-level dinner with unique interior then this is the place for you. On the side note it was really loud, by the end of the dinner my throat was sore from shouting across the table to my partner sitting just opposite me.

DZX8Hzdpo2g4Av47UF6cTw.text: After seeing some of the cute branded enamel plates pop up on Instagram (clever marketing ploy, guys), I decided to try out Brasserie Zédel for my birthday dinner. A group of 6 of us met up in the Bar Americain and were treated to some well-mixed cocktails with polite and efficient table service in a kitschy but affectionately intimate approximation of a 30s Parisian Bar.From there we were whisked to our table in the restaurant itself - an over-the-top marbled deco paean to the Grand Brasseries of Montparnasse. In some ways it's too big - I later found out that my brother and his wife had been dining there at exactly the same time and we neither knew nor saw each other! Service was good, not too intrusive despite the fact that some of our party arrived at different times. The wine is great value but the food was a mixed affair: a dainty starter of frogs legs was tasty but trop petit. My choucroute lacked a bit of punch somehow; a friend complained his lamb was dry, but others seemed happy with their choices. Unfortunately there was no time to sample desserts as we had a booking at Le Crazy Coqs, the cabaret bar that makes up the rest of this venue.And THAT was fantastic, with great service, delicious signature cocktails and a charming performer. As an all-round experience it was a great night out... and for a moment I felt transported to another time and place. But the food (while great value) is a little hit and miss.

ZImVgFm4lTjOVygf1zghOw.text: A insanely huge busy restaurant. Group of four seated at table, which was probably slightly too small to accommodate us comfortably. A nice wine selection and great plat du jours, which I ended up getting. Would come back again. (Visit - 29/05/2014 Dinner)

EXwdAJNE_iQWoqJSx2cr5A.text: Great and fast service and good French food. It's like being transported in France for the time of the diner. Better book before going or you'll queue.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Trout
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Snails with garlic
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. French restaurant style just footsteps from Piccadilly

Rc6j_Y-96qvSr0ENqwDZBw.text: Oh my!  Much like other reviewers, I found Brasserie Zedel very good!  Service was excellent!  Food was amazing, I had the beef bou...well, you know how it's spelled....And the prices are excellent to boot.  The only thing is that it is quite cavernous inside and the noise level was very high.  There is a strong echo factor meaning everyone's conversations and the clanking of the cutlery sounded much louder than it needed to be.  And I don't mind loud but it was a bit much for my taste.  Toilets are quite nice and fancy.  :) But I'd go again, but prepared with ibuprofen beforehand to avoid a noise headache.

g0a8SyZ40KZ_b4dVhwsazA.text: This is a wonderful place to have a meal, a well priced menu, delicious hearty food and a lovely wine list. The room itself is glorious, vast and ornate. A great place for any occasion, whether you're on your own, on a date or out with family. My nephews get excited about visiting London just so they can go to Zedel and have snails!

SjsxN2z83yQJ-WMjLYzgGQ.text: The room is spectacular and you feel like you have been transported to a huge brasserie in Paris or are in Grand Central Station in NYC.  And then you get a traditional French menu which is always exciting.  (I love French food and seeing escargot on the menu makes me oh so happy!)  The bread by the way was really good.Come here prepared to eat a lot of heavy French food and it is well executed (although Paris is better) so you won't be too disappointed.

sJ5KnIHAbqLubpPwzl4wjw.text: This place is crazy. Once you walk through the little cafe area at the front of the establishment, you find yourself descending a huge staircase into what can only be described as the lobby of a 1920's hotel or cinema (or both). It's a bit surreal.We went to the Bar Americain to have a few drinks. This was after the nine boozes I had at lunch and before the many more boozes I was going to have at Clockjack Oven. The seating area in the bar also has a very 1920's feel to it. There's a grandiose bar along one wall and the bartender and server were dressed to go with the decor.Of course, they serve old fashioneds which two of my drinking companions ordered, but I opted for some other drinks from the menu, both of which were fantastic.What a cool place to come for cocktails in the afternoon. They even supplied us with complementary spicy almonds and olives!

IX0LcqwzlzOhs6JNJphT5g.text: What a place! The entrance is grand, the chandelier, the floor, the art work, everything just sets the place off so when you walk in to the brasserie you realise the entrance is just the beginning.   The staff are wonderful, attentive and helpful without being too much.   I ate the Confit de Canard which was so indulgent but wonderful, just the right amount and at a very decent price. There were 2 of us, we had a main, two sides and 2 desserts with the whole meal coming to £80 including service. For central London, wonderful food and a beautiful setting, it is totally worth it

fbW_nLy7i-zDtqFT27Nk8A.text: This place is a great find! Tucked away from the madness of Piccadilly, this is a French oasis that makes for a lovely meal that won't break the bank. I came here with a few friends for a pre-theatre meal a few nights ago.We were led into a large room with tall ceilings and nice lighting. It felt very much like a French brasserie on a much larger scale. The menu was extensive with something for everyone. I opted for the onion soup and smoked mackerel while my friends had the steak-frites, sea bream, and seabass. We will split two very nice bottles of red. We had some coffee and creme brulee for dessert. The meal was solid. Very tasty and everyone was satisfied. The prices were extremely reasonable given the quality of the food and how nice the ambiance was. I completely regret not finding this place sooner as I would love to be a regular. The service was excellent. We told them of our hard stop to head to the theater and they did everything they could to help us get on our way in time. I would absolutely recommend this place for a pre-theatre meal or dinner generally. I could also see this being a great choice for brunch or lunch.

QcalQnAyqy1qdiyym-TCHQ.text: What a beautiful restaurant. You felt you were in Paris. The food was fabulous. You can tell the service team was really a team. They all worked together. We were impressed with the food and service. My duck was soooo goood. I could have it again.

kpA11v8UW5GCKFOmdSN9CA.text: Safe to say I have found my new favourite restaurant in London! Dined on a Thursday evening, with a 45 minute wait for a table for 2, but it was more than worth it. Whole experience was grand from start to finish, with pre dinner drinks in the bar (Aviator - absolutely delightful! £9.50 a drink, but to be expected in the surroundings) followed by swiftly being whisked to the table by their ever attentive staff. The building and atmosphere really make this place, with high ceilings and elegant decor, this is a fantastic venue for a date, groups of friends or taking a client. Very reasonably priced food too, with the steak hache at under £10, as was the beef bourguignon - both with sides included.  Will certainly be back!

P8VeEwoYnEUwf3JTTEmaaw.text: Considering the fake made corporate owned brasserie right around the corner from Piccadilly, I'm always surprised how much I enjoy it here, from the large comfortable space, the service, and the tasty food that is not as expensive as you would think it would be (at least in the heart of London's tourist district, relatively speaking). Has become a good standby and their prix-fix are great deals and while it's busy, the space is large enough to get seating (although maybe I'm just really lucky now that I'm reading other people saying reservations are must). Also open very late with live jazz bands playing sometimes. LOVE the space.

TDVx7-UTGQfsExvvDIw3cg.text: My friends and I went for a Friday night dinner, and it was solid.First, the food was great.  I ordered the beetroot and goat cheese salad for starter, then the steak with pepper sauce and chips for main.  I particularly liked my starter -- it was both fresh and tasty in an authentic French way.  I enjoyed my main as well, though I did feel like it was a bit lacking in creativity.  Solid, but 2% shy of perfection.  Finally, the creme brulee was on the dot and came in healthy portions as well.Second, the service was phenomenal.  Our waitress was prompt and kind, even patient enough to bring out two types of wine for us to try and decide upon.  Given how busy the restaurant was, I was quite impressed with the high quality of service. Finally, the ambience was top notch.  Once we climbed down the stairs, we found a spacious, glamorous space before us, making it hard to believe we were even in London anymore.  There seemed to be a performance going on at the same time in the adjacent room as well.  It'd be great if I could combine food with a performance next time I'm here.Overall, a great experience and highly recommended when you find yourself in the happening Piccadilly Circus.

oK309rJb3HyboHz0b2SJOw.text: Overall food tasted nice. Been two times. Once at 1pm and another at 3pm. The first time we went was at 1PM and food was very delicious especially the seafood. However, the second visit, food came very fast and noticed it was not very hot and just heated which was very disappointing. However, we could still taste the freshness of the food.

uxoNOOaMM116ZpLvAcgCeA.text: Grand hall tucked away under Piccadilly Circus.  Despite the location, it didn't seem to be that tourist-packed.  Decor is a sprawling high-ceilinged room with loads of gold accents.  Really nailed the French Brasserie vibe and has the menu to match (in French with some English translations).  I ordered the Steak Bordelaise and the sauce was out of this world!  The meat was also cooked to the perfect tenderness and went down quickly with some frites.  Service was a little on the slow side even for a Sunday night, but other than that a very enjoyable experience!

liGmR0h3rUPklhHmXPv9HQ.text: This place is uber with a capital oooh.  It's like walking into the 1920s and also really quite like walking into the Brasserie Georges in Lyon.  This really is as good as France gets, set a hundred years in the past and located in London. The food is fabulous, the prices are even easier to digest, they have live jazz, I just love it.  I really could wax lyrical about it for ages but I won't so you will need to go there for yourselves to check it out.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

B9daJBTRsogrUsWHVg3PFA.text: Visited for the Bastille Day celebrations and decided to have the Menu Formule which is a set price of £19.75. Included in that are 3 courses, a glass of red or white wine and a coffee to finish. For value for money it probably can't be beaten in the area.  The actual meal itself was mainly a hit. The starter of Céleri Rémoulade felt like more of a side and is not something I'll be rushing to try again however it's not the worst thing I've ever had but the Bœuf Bourguignon was fantastic. Big chunks of beef just falling apart and tasty creamy mash. This was definitely the highlight. The dessert of Ile Flottante was also tasty and was just enough to finish the meal off.  While the meal is ok Brasserie Zédel is more about the experience. The dining room is fantastic and has to be seen to be believed and the staff were all very helpful and extremely knowledgeable about both the food and the wine. This is a place you need to visit

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Free meal just for wearing a crown!

SfVTPCLRY8PLDoqICdmciA.text: I went there for the third time this weekend and had a great time as usual. I had the duck (Magret de Canard Rôti) which was cooked to perfection; however, as I have a big appetite and the portion wasn't as filling as I would have liked. For being such a lush and popular venue the prices are very reasonable in any case. Although it is located in the tourist hotspot of Piccadily it doesn't feel touristy at all, and as it's a classy place and isn't over-priced I've been there before with my parents and friends before, and will definitely go back again. I would give it 5 stars if the portions were bigger, and I also had a very slow waiter this time which was annoying when wanting to order another drink and ask for another side.

pEyRHhWILhYLxD9lEmbZSg.text: Had dinner last week with a friend. Had the boeuf bourgignon and shared escargot for starters. Food was delicious, if a little stodgy. Plentiful bread basket which was welcome. Good value wine which was delicious. Service was fabulous. A fantastically decorated restaurant, a real hidden gem. Will go again.

01BEB80BAuHLSErEOmXoVA.text: You know those turn of the century, massive art deco styled, Parisian restaurants that only exist in Nazi occupied French films?  Well, you can pretend that Edith Piaf is going to waltz through the entrance at any time at Brasserie Zédel.The decor feels slightly tired, especially the bar area, but it's a great attempt at bringing an old style, Parisian bistro to central London.  The location is right off Piccadilly Circus and the food is solidly, traditionally French.  I had the endive and Roquefort salad with walnuts and then the choucroute Alsacienne.  The choucroute came with a little warming stand to keep the food hot.  Both dishes were yummy and I was happy with my food choices.The menu is great value too.  Starters, mains, side of veg, wine and coffees for two came out to £75 (including service).  Also, despite the size of the dining room, you can still have an intimate conversation with whoever you are dining with.  Tables are not packed in like in some restaurants and the noise level is manageable.  Definitely worth checking out if you are in the area!

Zoe9fJrBiy5dZFuMLB4AVQ.text: We tried to get into lupa Di bocca I think it's called, but the hostess referred us to this place a block away since they were closed. It looked a little 'commercial' or not really our style, but when we went downstairs to eat, the dining room was very impressive, so beautiful and we really enjoyed the food! We just had a simple salad, some sides and the fish. The only complaint was the waiter seemed annoyed that we ordered things to share as we weren't really hungry, but he was attentive for the rest of the meal. A piano player started playing as we were leaving. I would def recommend!

ky46gwhW9aT3pKhspHgsHQ.text: Maybe the romanticism of being on a first date (with my now husband) wore off because I was even less impressed with Zedel nearly 4 years later. Don't get me wrong, this is a really interesting find in Piccadilly Circus and the architecture is still impressive and the atmosphere is still outstanding, but the food and service just don't hit the mark in the slightest.My little sister and her boyfriend were visiting from NY and so we decided to take them here since it's in a touristy area, but kind of hidden (in terms of 'you wouldn't expect something like this to exist here') and also has a nice vibe. We arrived at 930pm on a Wednesday for our reservation and the placed was packed, so we needed to wait for our table. When we were finally seated we were smashed into a tiny booth right by the bar. Which was kind of annoying given there were open tables in other areas and also, my husband is 6'4" 240lbs and my sister's boyfriend isn't far off from that. But it was fine, I am used to being elbowed by my leftie husband every time he cuts his food and shovels it into his mouth anyway (hehe). The next thing that was annoying was that we were given menus in French, which was clearly on purpose given that fact that we spoke ENGLISH whilst ordering our bottle of wine and other drinks at the bar. Blah blah blah, we order food and it comes. I specifically asked the waiter if the lobster cocktail had mayo in it like a typical disgusting British prawn cocktail and he said no... well when it came, it did. I was a little annoyed but didn't say anything because I didn't want to sour the mood. Second course comes and my husband goes to eat his steak and as he is taking his second bite he gets a taste of truffle, which he HATES with a passion. I don't understand how anyone can hate truffles, but he does and refuses to eat anything with truffles involved. He requested the menu and it did not say ANYWHERE on the menu that the butter on the steak is in fact truffle butter (but I guess we could be thankful it wasn't the Nicki Minaj kind). While this may be a pleasant surprise for most, it was not for him. Thankfully they offered to take the steak off the bill and he had an excuse to go eat a Big Mac. I had the scallops and they were pretty unimpressive. I only ate half of my main, which is not like me since I am a giant food beast.The only redeeming quality of the evening is that there was a live jazz band playing - though we were seated too far away from them to really hear them or enjoy it. I could overhear the first date that was happening on the bar stools two feet from us more clearly.Come here if your idea of good food is going to a Harvester.

3nDOkRcLaRDd0AktHtJDjQ.text: Came here on the recommendation of our EWR-LHR United flight attendant who is French. You have to enter through the bar and go down two flights of stairs to the gorgeous cavernous dining hall. Husband had the fish and chips, which was light and crispy. I had the chopped steak au poivre which was good. Nice wine selection and live accordion music. Would return.

HJbdHVEEBtxaQeHpLo9rJg.text: To be honest its about 2.5 stars. Their prix fixe and formule offer a great value for the pre theater crowd. Their decor and vibe are a solid four stars as it feels as you have been whisked to a Paris brasserie as there was a guy playing the 88 keys. Perhaps I am spoiled having spent time in Paris and live in the SF Bay Area but their food was not memorable. Very basic barely passable French. Their service also seemed a bit disjointed as I quite frankly didn't know who our server was. I can't say I'll be back. At least "we'll always have Paris".

ESLDxWNrELA7xFxxvSiJ_w.text: What a wonderful experience, took my mother here for her birthday to the brassiere and it was enjoyed by all. Great food and great service - warning though menu is in French. The staff was very attentive and explained anything we didn't understand also very good topping up the drinks, they were also good with children and keeping them entertained. The cost was average or cheap for so central so highly recommend but there is 15% service charge. If you like Art Deco this is the place for you all has been kept original from the hotel and the bar has the decor by far

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Lovely architecture
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Cocktail bar worth a visit

SKMlLjAKPkRQ9VaK1p0h6w.text: I've been back a few times now and it hasn't improved. Perhaps it's a lot busier now and therefore they have let their service slip? Either way, not the gem it once was.

iQX694fgL6JpCvQ4d7A0NQ.text: Such a cool little spot in a busy part of london! the main restaurant is amazing, like walking into a film - and the food is just as good. very cheap too considering - main meals are about 9-10 pounds, and 5 pounds for dessert - we had the ile flottante which was just beautiful!waitress was lovely too - totally recommend this place!

uIXKV4YDtwuPPnCS_IPAww.text: We had an amazing time and excellent food. We didn't know where we were going when we went to Piccadilly Circus and stumbled on this great restaurant. Nice people, even though we weren't completely dressed appropriately. Please try this nice surprise!

NqeiUMjIcItFJS7MvmAysg.text: Brasserie Zedel is truly a hidden gem in London, and it seems it has just got a touch better if I was to directly compare it to my last visit. One of the great things about this restaurant is its always buzzing atmosphere, along with the classic brasserie decor, feels just as if you are in France, this place is perfect for a date or for families. Service was also decent, not overly formal or careless. To sum it up, if you are a fan of traditional French food, Brasserie Zedel is a great choice. It might not be the very best in London, but totally value for money, in a superb location.

Qnps5iFsyGkPzG9EGTM1xA.text: This is place is massive, opulent and covered in gold and french. I loved it!The Bar Americaine is wonderful place for a quiet drink with friends or a first date. Swanky enough to leave a good impression but not leave you broke. The drinks are good, there was definitely time and care taken to make them. The restaurant is nice, reminds of me all the brassieres i've ever been to. The long bar and huge restaurant gala. I ordered the duck confit (my go to) with white beans and it was really good. My partner had the Escargot which was also very tasty, and followed by the steak & frittes. All of which was very good and tasty, the ambiance was lovely as well as the service. The desserts were traditional and now so great but alas, the rest of it was pretty great.

iWW6NydlrYOksM26gjZXug.text: Before I write this review, I hasten to add that I suspect on a good day, this is a place well and truly worthy of an extra star. I think I was probably unlucky in the time and day I went...!Anyway, a group of myself and nine friends had ordered a table to eat here last Tuesday evening. It's easy to get to, the setting is absolutely gorgeous, and our orders were taken quickly and efficiently. The service for the starters was very quick indeed, probably given that the starters were mostly raw: we pretty much all picked set menus, and the Prix Fixe and Formule menus give you carottes râpées and céleri rémoulade respectively as a starter!For the main, however, the service was disappointingly slow. It must have taken nearly an hour after we had finished our starter to bring our main (which given pretty much the entire table was eating rare steak haché, or the beef bourguignon which was probably cooked in bulk, is a little surprising!). The food for both courses was good, well-cooked (or rather, perfect all the more because it wasn't cooked too much, as it's supposed to be!) and reasonable French food. It was nothing that would blow your mind, but it was tasty and well-prepared.The other blow to the service came after pudding - one member of our table had been waiting half an hour for a glass of wine they'd ordered, and four of the coffees supposed to come with the Formule menu didn't arrive... I will give the place the benefit of the doubt and assume this was not an intentional attempt to see if slightly more merry customers (luckily I wasn't drinking that evening!) would forgo their coffee, but it does make one wonder... Anyway, the waitress wasn't particularly helpful or polite when dealing with the request RE: the wine, trying to insist that we'd had the glass and pointing at the glasses of other members of the table, who had been drinking their wine far before my friend had ordered his (never received) glass... She was rather shirty considering we were the one who'd been slighted, and by this point the restaurant was almost empty, so she didn't even have the excuse of juggling several tables at once.Overall, the place has good, well-prepared standard French food, and the setting is beautiful, but the service is a little hit-and-miss. If you've a spare hour, don't go in case you don't finish in time; if you've a spare two/three, you'll probably have a wonderful evening!

TLw07TZ4B624-0xXUJvTTQ.text: Was recommended by my sister's boyfriend, who knows London better than anyone I personally know, and he couldn't have been more spot on with this suggestion! Wish I was a little dressed up more, but that's on me. Great atmosphere, friendly service, wonderful decorations, wish I was able to stay for the nighttime jazz.

nmx744QrgSgHaDH4BV5PSQ.text: What an amazing find in London! Where do I begin?! First off you walk through a casual ground level cafe to a flight of stairs that seems to take you through time. You enter at a below ground level lobby that takes you to the roaring 20's and everything Art Deco you could imagine. There is a coat check, a dark and sculptured bar/lounge and an amazing nude marble grand room. It used to be a substantial hotel, and the dining room does not disappoint. It is is large and beautiful, yet you are still able to have an intimidate meal.The menu is everything delicious and diving straight from a Parisian menu. There were so many options that I wanted to sample, we ended up over ordering for the table. We sampled the French onion soup, potato leak soup, carrot salad, celery salad, potato and leak tart, poivre steak, pommes frites with Bernaise sauce, seafood in puff pastry and house fish. The offer great prix fixed menus ranging from ten to twenty pounds. Quite a bargain for three courses some including a glass of house wine.For dessert we had truffles, profiteroles, coffee and cake and our favorite the floating island dessert.We had a few kinks in our service, but the manager more then made up for it. So in our books it was a five star meal.I cannot wait to go back to London to visit Brasserie Zedel again. Thank goodness I don't live closer, because I don't think that my waistline could handle it.

zMqPZfeF6QNqczuetU_2bw.text: Brasserie Zedel is right off the Piccadilly Circus tube station, boasting its central location and posh burlesque style. The brasserie itself is downstairs, so be prepared to have no service connection.Once you are downstairs, you'll find yourself in a beautiful spacious and brightly lit hall. It is advisable to make a reservation, especially for a large party as it gets pretty busy on a weekend.The service was very nice and professional. We were in a group of 9 people and got a complimentary dessert liqueur shots on the house at the end of our meal.The food was comforting, I tried chicken fois  gras and escargot in garlic sauce. I wasn't very much convinced by the escargot as they came with no shell and seemed less authentic. I had profiteroles with hot chocolate poured on top for dessert and they were absolutely delicious! Definitely worth a try ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Fois Gras and Escargot with no shells at the right far end
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Boeuf Bourguignon is nice
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Profiteroles with hot chocolate poured on top are absolutely delicious!!

ata0Woy7bMd9IZw0_ebwmA.text: Frankly, this place may be a object lesson of style over substance, but nevertheless, it's worth coming here just for the expansive, beautiful dining room and live gypsy jazz.  The food ranged from fine to good--the crème brûlée was excellent--and you can order drinks from the Bar Americain.  Service was a little brusque and transactional, but you can't have everything.  Be sure to catch a show at The Crazy Coqs as well!

BUFwOfgaNU3RC3Go6mSVxQ.text: Stellar menu and perfectly prepared dishes! Almost too much to choose from. Their daily prix fixe menus are bargains.

hXI_njOxMI9kqRAL2r1Q5Q.text: Brasserie Zédel is my favourite restaurant in central London, if not all of London. You can eat cheaply or blow the budget; the menu has plenty of options. Tables are held back specifically for walk-ins so you can generally get a table easily apart from special occasions or just after a national paper publishes another good review.Out of the starters, I recommend the soup (currently leek and potato but changes regularly) and the chicken liver parfait (a firm menu staple).Mains-wise, the fish fillet (there's always sea bream and/or sea bass on the menu), duck (accompaniments change but generally always on the menu) and choucroute (firm staple) are always lovely. For those who don't really like French food (really?), there's the steak haché (like a skinny burger with fries) or goujonettes (fish bites with fries).All the deserts are epic - ask your server for a recommendation. If you are feeling full, you just have a solitary scoop of ice cream or sorbet (they will charge you less). Try to save room for a "real" dessert though.If you're in a rush, let someone know and they will turn your table pretty quickly. Some sections are looked after better than others and I recommend ordering drinks immediately as sometimes they can take a while to turn up and you don't want your starters to arrive before your drinks do. Regarding water, the servers are quite happy to bring you tap water and will discreetly replace an empty carafe with a full one whilst you're tucking into your food.In the evenings there is live piano music, but if you're into performing arts, there's usually a show on at The Crazy Coqs at 8pm or so. It's the venue up the stairs and is the most Art Deco looking part of what is truly a gorgeous building. Zédel is a feast for the eyes as well as the stomach.The Bar Américain is a great place to wait for a table (the staff will let you know when one is ready) and they do great cocktails, including off-menu ones. Just be aware that it's very expensive. You can eat at the Brasserie on a budget, but the Bar is never cheap (unless you're on bottled water, which is only a quid).ZL Café upstairs is fab for having a coffee or quick lunch/snack, but it closes quite early. Many people mistake it for the Brasserie - the Brasserie is downstairs. There's a lift if you need one and a free baggage check (tips welcome).I'm always treated well at Zédel. Great food and service.

2RDCQyh0BDoFhbC78PrdHA.text: Good food, good price, good space, good value. It's not the fancy pansy spot and that's why it's so cool. Service is seamless but with character, food is of quality and quantity - which is quite rate this day. Wine list is consistent and includes all ranges and the pricing is subtle and coherent. It's great worth friends. Wouldn't go for a romantic Dinner there thought is super busy

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

ydm1nyCVHATWoZ-JVt8C0Q.text: I'm a born and bred Londoner who is not a huge fan of central London, particularly Oxford Circus/Picadilly Circus, so when a friend suggested this place, I didn't have high hopes. I was in for quite a surprise...The first surprise is the entrance. Even though the small, cute, French-looking cafe your walk into is nice, it doesn't prepare you for the beautiful, decadent, art-deco style interior as you walk downstairs. My next big surprise came when I saw the prices... considering it's central London, the prices are incredibly cheap with a set menu starting at around £13. The food is generally pretty good - not amazing - but good. having said that, if you're a creme brûlée fan like me, order that! You won't be disappointed.

hb22H5hy-Of8ZOTW9pCfIA.text: You wouldn't think from the outside that once you go down the stairs and in the main room you'd feel as if you are in Paris! But you just do :-)I have been a few times and always happy to go back.Last time I had the snails, the entrecote and the lemon tart. All was wonderful! The snails as you would expect in gorgeous parsley butter, the entrecote cooked to perfection (medium/rare) and the lemon tart was a delicious end to the meal.The service was great as well, impressive considering the number of tables.

iYFtGXRadzcBojxzf-ZDVQ.text: The outstanding thing about this place is the interior decor. Converted from an Art Deco hotel the dining room downstairs is the opposite from what you'd expect from the small cafe style entrance on the ground floor. They've kept the theming going throughout with the beautiful antique posters on the wall as you venture downstairs and the dining hall is so grand with tall pillars and decadence of gold and burgundy. It had a similar air to the dining hall in The Shining (I see this as a good thing). The food itself was nice, nothing too spectacular but very pleasant. I know they also have a separate bar and run other events also which would be good to check out

ufXBOIUBkRdtowrnJNcOaw.text: I call this "my favourite French restaurant in London". I have to be honest, the food is not outstanding - hence the four star review - but there's a variety on offer and it's all good value. I'd recommend the prix fixe menus but personally grated carrots just doesn't do me as a starter. What I absolutely adore here is the ambiance and the decoration. It was refurbished in the original Art Deco style a few years ago and walking down the stairs to the main foyer never fails to impress friends. It's stunning. What's more, there's often live music playing in the main restaurant and the excellent service coupled with the surroundings essentially makes you feel like you've gone back to another age. After eating in the evening you can also visit their (more expensive) cocktail bar and jazz bar. It's pretty much like this place was invented for me, to be honest.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. So much gold! The wooden bench is the waiters' station.
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Ladies toilet, even luxurious here!

pb5uFoo9pS2ZVvfLuUwoTg.text: This place is spectacular to walk into and the staff couldn't be friendlier, however I found the food a little disappointing. It is very reasonably priced but just didn't live up to my expectations, I ordered the hanger steak rare and it was more on the side of medium and not as tasty as I would have liked! A friend of mine ordered off their vegetarian menu (which you have to ask for separately) and was served a cauliflower and cheese mush. I had very high expectations of the place and in every other aspect (wine, ambience, staff, coffee...) it lived up to them, it was just a shame about the food, perhaps I ordered the wrong thing?

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

V8JorCsfuqxQ3rMkRp_XhQ.text: Fabulous French decor for starters: perfect imitation of a Parisian cafe when you enter. Headed downstairs, there is a such grand art deco, it's fabulous. The dining room is all gilt and large clocks and waiters in proper black-and-white dress. I got the carrots with Dijon sauce and the broccoli quiche. The first was light and tasty, with just enough Dijon mustard. The quiche was DELICIOUS. Soft and so buttery. For less than 10 quid for my meal, I was pleasantly happy. The service was also very good: far better than your typical London establishment. The crowd seemed to be a mix of tourists and Londoners.

c0PRkacU9rG7zmj-2LmefQ.text: This place did not disappoint! Absolutely gorgeous decor, will make you feel like you're in Paris in the 20s  Great atmosphere with helpful waiters and live jazz from a pianist playing just behind us.There's a great selection of French wines, with a waiter ready to name for us exactly what to get to match our mains. Food came in small portions, but was delicious! I recommend getting the peach sorbet with champ ang for dessert - they pour the champagne for you and get in when the champagne is still filming and you'll get a great shot to show off to friends. Overall, just a great way to spend your night in London, especially with this lovely gem being so close to Piccadilly Circus station.

X5iCSlg3N9eEC5O0GYGESw.text: Had dinner at Brasserie Zédel for pre-theatre which is one of their most popular time!The service was very fast and our Portuguese waiter was excellent! His services was worthy of a fine dining establishment with great menu recommendations! The Steak Tartare was a bit of a let down as the meat was minced too thinly and worked way too much with sauces. I'm sure the quality was good to start with but the taste was lost in the mise en place process. I would highly recommend to make a table reservation to avoid disappointment!

i-m2qzsQ6h-xLMkxtoLa2Q.text: I just came back from two weeks in France, and I wish the food had been as delicious as our lunch at Zedel was.  We started with escargot, served piping hot with a garlic parsley butter. Thank goodness we had bread to soak up the excess. Then coquilles st Jacques, scallops for Americans, served with their coral on a bed of crunchy cooked veggies with a broiled creamy sauce on top. And for dessert, opera cake for my daughter and profiteroles for me. Perfect. The decor is beautiful (pink linens, marble walls, high ceilings, lots of glass and brass).

hi56ekUzj5tkUU9WOcGYdA.text: Fantastically Luxe/ Art Déco venue. The food & staff are exceptional and we managed to get a seat without difficulty on a busy Friday night at 10.30pm!

mhLjRCxbr9Cfgng5lU9JyQ.text: A throwback to the Roaring '20s, Brasserie Zédel is an excellent place to score a perfected signature cocktail.  With great music to match the scene, a generally fully house, and a number of delicious cocktail choices, this is sure to please either before going out to dinner, or for some post-dinner drinks.  The few downsides worth noting would include:  service can be slow, double-check your bill (we got charged for a bottle, instead of a glass, of wine), and the drinks aren't cheap (think £12-£14- range for a premium cocktail).  But it's worth it for the glamorous experience, the mood lighting and music, and a start to a wonderful evening in the heart of London

ISC5vBTCLzWQHpu4HzlwQQ.text: Brasserie Zedel is a crazy place. It doesn't look like much from the outside but after walking through the small cafe area and down the stairs you are confronted with a huge restaurant. We arrived at 2 pm on a Saturday without a reservation and every table was taken so we waited at the bar. The staff were really good and allowed us to snack on bread while we waited but the table was ready after 15 minutes wait.I ordered the steak and chips which was delicious and didn't break the bank. Now I now it is here I will try and return as it is such a good spot for lunch.

qUZKOWC_8ze8ShkopgfdcA.text: Service was pretty bad. Most waiters were not attentive, and was not available to service customers. The food very pretty average as well. We ordered the french onion soup, chopped steak, snail and they were all average. Would not recommend this place!

jXKmS50Q2-z1d0Nj9hxnDQ.text: Love the dining experience in this basement art we go French restaurant. We ordered a lunch 3 course menu only cost £19.90 which a very good value. It is very popular restaurant here and it tend to be very noisy when it is full.

wQM5OCv_0YVAcFJmQupE5w.text: It's a bit in the expensive side but the quality is really nice and the service is amazing! It's also great for group get together. I Went there to have a 10 person lunch and we spent about £21 per person  and we are well. The food is French. It's great French from lovely delicious, crispy but moist fish. The almond trout looked amazing! To great meat. I had beouf burginon and a friend had s state great reviews. The downside is that some mains you may be recommended to order a side as well but the sides are great. The atmosphere really makes you feel like you're in 1920s or Belle Époque Paris with grand columns and gold color ornamentation. The waiters were absolutely amazing. They were always there in time to fill my water and delivered the food quite quickly. It was honestly amazing service that makes you feel a bit fancy. Overall recommend. Great food, beautiful place,amazing service. Warning you may have to spend a bit but it's nice treat :D

XgfZxC13R8mN5Uh5thquSA.text: I was very excited to visit this restaurant after I reading multiple reviews. However, while the ambiance was spectacular, the food did not quite live up to my expectations. I ordered the duck on a bed of capers and my friend ordered a beef fillet from the deluxe menu. We shared the frog legs appetizer. The frog legs were great! I definitely do not recommend sharing the appetizer because the size is somewhat small. The reason I was disappointed is because my duck was drier than other duck dishes I have had. My friend was also not blown away by his fillet. All in all, the food was good (not great) and the service was superb! The staff is attentive and amenable to us splitting the check. I would definitely recommend coming at least once if you are in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Duck on capers (was a little dry)
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. The frog legs as an appetizer was great! (Do not share)

N2dj5cp58pC0gt5FgoqNzg.text: Wonderful Cafe!My cousin and I actually just randomly went inside this cafe for a hot drink because it was storming outside and we needed refuge ha haWe were delighted to see what a lovely place this was! Everything you would expect from a posh cafe. We ordered some hot chocolates along with a piece of cake. I'm not sure exactly what entire place is but it looked something like a hotel minus the accommodations if that makes sense? lol Very confusing. There was this fancy bar and restaurant downstairs that we didn't get to try but it looked super expensive. I would love to come back when I have more time to try the restaurant portion downstairs.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Hot Chocolate and piece of cake
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Terrible photo, but this is downstairs and across you can see the bar and to the side of the bar (not photographed) is the restaurant.

_mp0_xvFkhfGVPIptShAzg.text: My husband and I dined in this classy dining room -- decked out in marble, gold, a large wall clock, and fancy table settings -- last Sunday for brunch. I ordered the French onion soup and Quiche Lorraine (under £6 each) while my husband went with the three-course Prix Fixe, which currently includes a carrot salad appetizer, beef patty covered in sauce and fries main, and a slice of dessert (similar to tiramisu) for under £13. I was expecting more cheese to cover the soup (there was a very small amount) and the quiche to be thicker (it was pretty thin), but otherwise, I enjoyed the taste of both (and actually, I understand the smaller portion sizes because they were under the appetizer section rather than the mains, and this appears to be a nicer place). The crust on the quiche was the highlight of my meal. The French menu is their standard menu and does include descriptions underneath the names of some dishes in small print in English, but they also have an English menu, so ask for it if you don't speak French and would like to know what everything actually is. Overall, I thought the ambiance was nice, but not my personal taste, and the food was okay. The service was quite good.Note: You need to take the elevator down to get to this formal dining room.

yw2DyT6touG2sFItwAAPcQ.text: After a long and successful run, I'm just starting to wonder whether this restaurant is in danger of becoming a victim of it's own success. Trying to even get into the bar area at around 730pm is next to impossible with wait times of over 20 minutes. At £12 for a cocktail it might be worth meeting elsewhere for a pre dinner drink. The service in the restaurant itself is good but it seems to me that the food prices are rising and no longer represent exceptional value for money. Saying that I would recommend the trout with almonds as a main.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

drTrORbl85L9-NdyagL0EQ.text: The snails are good. I really like the garlic and parsley butter sauce. The fish stew is in fact seafood stew. I don't like the fish. Either they didn't pick the right type of fish or the fish is not fresh. I like the shrimps and mussels though. The cream brûlée is way too heavy. I can't even finish it. The dining environment is good. It looks fancy and it's good for dating.
