Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Dinner menu

Mw5Zo2sDInnFza6biYh0IA.text: Inexpensive French fare in the middle of the tourist shopping district.   Near Whole Foods.Our group of 5 walked in and was able to get a last minute seat but must vacate by 1:30 hours.   We agreed.Ordered our appetizers, meals using the now English menu.  Easy to understand and service efficient.Ran out of time to get dessert, staff mentioned.Ambience good selling point.Will come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Bill for group of 5 with 15% service charge 12/16
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Flank steak - med rare is best. 12/16
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Trout with almonds 12/16

3181MJLrb8RBOAtzplY6PA.text: I have no clue why I never knew about Zedels, it's right in the heart of London and I've walked past so many times without stopping or giving it a second look. From the outside it looks like a café, very much 'café rouge' in style. You can buy juices, coffees and teas, sandwiches cakes and pastries. However downstairs they have the restaurant and Bar Americana. So we opted to go to the restaurant after I looked at some of the yelp reviews, and it was worth the visit! I can honestly say I never knew such a fantastic place existed in London. The restaurant greets you with white marble, dark wood and exudes an air of French chic. This is by far one of the best dining experiences I've had in a  while. I opted for the Prix Fixe 2 courses. It came with: Grated carrot starter - absolutely amazing with fresh herbs and a  divine vinaigrette sauce. Fresh tasty bread and butter. Steak main with pepper sauce and a side of fries. I asked for blue and it came as expected blue, but not as expected, minced steak in a patty. However it was absolutely wonderful. Tasty, fresh and the fries, thin cut and crispy, went extremely well with the peppercorn sauce. Delightful. All this washed down with a nice Boudreaux. Not only was the food amazing, felt authentically French, the quality was great, but this is the best service I have had in a very long time. The waiter constantly refilled our water and wine glasses, was extremely attentive, knowledgeable and overall rounded this great experience. The price for the Prix Fixe was a bargain £9.75. The wine was a little more expensive at £25 for a couple of glasses each, but was worth every penny. This is my new favourite London restaurant.

aIoSd3Y7HAh6a0cbcCSngw.text: What a room! Would rate higher but only stopped in for drinks. Top rate post-theatre stop!

s4jRNRgsMTv4AzBX8gVpuw.text: Swung into the Bar Americain last night. We took our first cocktails by the bar until our table was available. Sat down and drank up. A great place to hang out with friends, enjoy some classic concoctions, and having a few laughs.A top night indeed!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

4A6oFLG8cv1-lgsKuK26MQ.text: I was expecting so much more after reading these Yelp reviews!!!Got there right before noon, about 4 tables were occupied in the huge dining room and yet the person at the front desk had to look through the computer to see if he could find a table for me! I was given a menu and water quickly. I ordered the onion soup and the frisee salad. Yummy crusty bread and a small pot of butter arrived. While waiting for my food, the host tried to seat another person right next to me despite the mostly empty room. (That diner insisted on another table.) My soup came piping hot. It was good, though VERY salty. The salad arrived after I finished my soup. It was nicely presented and had a good flavor. That would have been the perfect meal but I was tempted by the creme brûlée which was also delicious but made me too full!! Service was lacking. I was ignored through most of my meal. Beautiful dining room AND bathrooms. A bit high for lunch, I paid £19.55, no alcohol.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Frisee salad just right
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. rich creme brulee
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. too salty onion soup

D9M49rxWXAO2hD-P3tZBvQ.text: I am absolutely a smitten kitten when it comes to this place. I vow to never miss an opportunity to return when in London.The staff are magical people from another land and I'm madly in love with each and every oneof them.The food: we only had dessert, but the truffles were life changing. I wept. Seriously. Tears.We had cocktails in one of the bars and I proposed marriage to my cocktail.This place is heaven. At least, I hope it is. And if it is, I'm going to be really, really good until the day I die so I can go there.

EE30Q58nSmqI0iim5K8idQ.text: If I could give 6 stars I would. Everything was amazing. The food was fantastic, the environment was authentic and lively, and the service was great. This was a highlight of the trip and I will make a point of coming back again.

t-1MNdzEgOFqSu01OVYpug.text: This is a nice French bistro located in Picadilly on the lower level. The service was excellent and the food was good. Started with the carrots - highly recommended, endive salad, onion soup, and the terrine. The terrine was rich and full of flavor, the endive salad and onion soup were both good. For main courses, tried the chopped steak with pepper sauce and the lamb sausage. Both were vey good. The only thing would enhance the experience would be to sit outside while enjoying the food.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Chopped steak with pepper sauce
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Lamb sausage

l4gAfpKrYqRKjoninxIoZA.text: This was a great find. Great place to have dinner before or after catching a show on one of the nearby theaters. If you go before a show, they inquire when your show starts and make sure your service knows what time you need to leave by to make your show. Great service and good food.

4i9Mp0G0TXjpgioAuWwuig.text: Loved the ambience but food was a let down. I have been there twice. The first time was good while on the second time, the french onion soup was served cold.Overall a nice place to be for the ambience.

9zENj8q9YIQX6a4S-idj3w.text: The place to go if you want terrible service and management needs work they are overly busy and understaffed this was my second visit. I think I would have been better off at McDonald's. Run and run fast!

nmZ8Qloousg3dRgPUchqHA.text: Excellent staff! Delicious food! Beautiful ambiance!Had the Beef Bourguignon & felt I was in a cafeBrasserie in Paris.I will definitely return

5qqmPInDM_mo-2yqCrCRyg.text: We read a lot of good reviews before going there, but, honestly, the food was not good. The service and atmosphere are great. Professional and nice servers and hostess, but, we did not finish our food (three of us). We ordered a few different steaks and beef dishes and it was dry and just didn't taste good. Also, they bring just the meat and some sauce on it. No side, no decoration or anything else. Again, maybe it was that night, it was packed so we were surprised that the food was not that good.

z0tR6X7RsIrkit9WRFtkXQ.text: Love the old French style from this place. Menu is super basic for ok prices - one block from Piccadilly circus.It's a good place to grab a quick drink and rest for a little bit

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Good for small bites and drink ;)

s4QGP20QHRm7ieTOaWZPUA.text: Ever wanted to time travel on the cheap?If you've fantasized about experiencing the Roaring Twenties firsthand, this French restaurant, decked out in an Art Deco style, will be a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of Piccadilly Circus.The decor (from the furniture to the posters and to the high ceilings) wowed me as soon as I walked in. The food, unfortunately, didn't.I stopped by to sample their prix fixe menu, but I didn't realize that the price wasn't the only thing fixed about the menu. There are no appetizer, entrée, or dessert options. You can only chose to have two courses and three courses and since I don't eat meat, this was out of the question. Instead, I went for the special of the day for £15.75 (Thursday's lunch is the chicken braised with tomatoes, mushrooms, shallots, and tarragon) and a starter of six escargot for £9.75.The complimentary bread we received was rockhard, which was a huge disappointment since one of the main things I remember about my Parisian vacations is the delicious bread. Perhaps this foreshadowed the rest of the meal: the escargot was way too salty to appreciate any of the intricacies of the flavor. Same goes for the chicken. Our server was also extremely brusque and probably said about two words to us (after taking our order).Still, while this sounds a bit superficial, I think I might come back simply for the wow factor of the dining room in the basement if I'm ever in London again. Though I might opt for coffee and dessert instead of an entire meal...

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

J3abHVr7yxP1XtedY54Dog.text: Well, what can I say - it's just as beautiful and special downstairs as I remember from way back when this was The Atlantic. The staircase leading down from the main Brasserie is not quite as dramatic as the one I remember but you are still ascending into another, more glamorous world. There is a choice of three rooms, one obviously a smart restaurant, and we headed straight for the Bar Americain. Easily the smartest cocktail bar in town. We felt transported back to another time, even before the Atlantic era, very Agatha Christie with the bar tenders creating the most amazing concoctions in front of us. True feelgood entertainment, a rare treat!

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

NnKDN6cbQ8RGxaVy5fMnKg.text: I think the food here is Okay.  It didn't stand out as impressive but its slightly above average.  However, the best thing here is the impressive food hall and people working here.  Also the price is not that crazy expensive as well so it caters for most people considering where the location is.  Definitely a place to come to impress your friends from out of town.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

zrp-CVP1zVz-5rLlZqrC7Q.text: I'm a little torn with my experience here as initially I was wowed entering the grand dining room with high ceilings and extravagant decor. However the service and some dishes were lacking that extra special touch to make me readily return.Having eaten in France and other European countries I can say that quality was lacking in all the traditional dishes. The escargot was my favourite dish being full of flavour and tasty sauce to dip my bread in. The other starters I tried were the steak tartare, plain and not super fresh, along with the egg over asparagus, which was good.For main, I ordered the steak a la Bordelaise which I was quite disappointed being the most expensive selection. It came as I ordered it, medium, however it was very chewy. Also the sauce was quite plain, tasting no bone marrow and just some onion with red wine. The mashed potatoes were also plain, could have used more French butter. The green salad is simply a bunch of lettuce with a light dressing. They could have added more to make it special.Overall I felt like food quality reflected the prices. It is low for a reason. Service was intermittent. We had a large group so I understand but our server spilled a little wine when pouring into several glasses. These little touches reflect back into the review.One nice addition, albeit late was the jazz band performing at the end of our dinner. They were a delight and would have been nice during the entire meal, given they started about 9:30pm on a weeknight.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate mousse - light and fluffy
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Steak a la Bordelaise - chewy

8JJiAqH5LyAzgHIL99n7Fg.text: Perfect place for a pre-theatre meal. Extensive French menu with daily specials and everything from snails to Camembert on the cheese trolley for afters. The setting is charming with good service. We dined on beef bourguignon, hake, salmon, and veal sweetbreads--everyone agreed their meal was super.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

3jeHK8gqcew2H8I9bDPCfw.text: We were only in London for one night, acting on a recommendation from a friend we made reservations for Zédel.  We arrived early and enjoyed a bottle of wine and a lovely evening on the outside patio after which we headed downstairs for dinner.  I enjoyed fish for dinner with a side of asparagus and my wife had the French onion soup with shrimp avocado salad.  Our meal was tasty, seasoned nicely and plated with care.  The only downside to our evening was that the service was a tad slow.  Overall the experience was very nice, it was a nice  restaurant in a large stately basement room, well appointed and comfortable, the food was very nice and reasonably priced for London.  We will stop by and sup again the next time we are in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

FnoLZIg5pleYIrK-NXkWYQ.text: If you like the snobby Attitude to go with your meal then this is the place to dine. We opted to sit on the sidewalk to have a light dinner with drinks. The French onion soup was tasty and that was about it.

VAImQjsOgXl4ouww19fhtQ.text: We had reservation at 9:30. After we ordered all the food, only soup was delivered. Wait until 10:4and check why does it take so long, the lady said their printer has problem,so they did not receive our order. But it will be done in 3 minutes. Wait another 10 minutes, we decided not to eat there since we lost the appetite and feel very upset. When the restaurant treat you like idiot and gave you nonsense reason, it's not a good restaurant. They should apologize and give you the true reason. Never use excuses to cover your own mistake.

D4lFOdVOtXUnohGSrqtnUw.text: Good atmosphere but garbage food. I had the most flavorless cod and a tasteless hamburger patty in peppercorn sauce. I also ordered French onion soup that was flavorless and escargot that was fishy and gross. I will never ever come back and advise others to do the same. I'm not a hater, I'm just pissed I spent $80 and that the restaurant has reviews as good as it does because the food sucked.

NR_nvNWtudk7gkg2WZzL0g.text: This is an impressively-sized and decorated establishment, with some beautiful art deco fixtures.We had booked a table for 7 and ended up at one of the raised booths at the back which gives you a nice view back over the restaurant floor. We were dressed up but a lot of people were casually dressed which somewhat ruins the aesthetic but is probably good for tourists who have been out all day sightseeing. It's perfectly placed for a pre-theatre meal.The menu is quite complex and a fair amount of it is just in French which even though I have a fairly good basic command of the languages left me in the dark about what a fair few of the hors d'oeuvres and sides were.The prix fixe is cheap but I didn't think any element of it (carrots, steak hache, chocolate torte) looked particularly appetising although hear no significant complaints.My meal started well with decent bread and butter and steak tartare, which came without an egg but was very well flavoured. It came with worcestershire sauce and tabasco and I was a bit confusedMy main, the plat du jour - saucisse with puy lentils, was disappointing in that in came with no sauce so was basically dry lentils and meat. The saucisse tasted nice but appeared to be supplemented with a lot of bits of bacon which I didn't see the point of as they distracted from the taste of the saucisse. At £15.75 this was terrible value for what you got and I would advise against ordering this. Particularly bad as it was the dish of the day, which means the restaurant is highlighting a mediocre dish as the one to go for that day! Our sides of mashed potato and creamed spinach were fine, nothing of note.It took FOREVER to get the bill and during this time we were left without any drinks, even water. We ended up waiting about 30 minutes after we would have liked to leave, even after having stood up and put our coats on it took a few minutes before someone arrived (our main waiter having disappeared).Overall not bad but and a very interesting set up and history, but would not order the saucisse de toulouse again.

bgpl03s8DcPCZs9TAtVP8w.text: We came here post-theatre show for a late dinner. Reservations were made and we sat smack dab in middle with perfect views of a live band playing. The restaurant is dim, conversations are loud, but  the setting is relaxing... funny how that works!I got the steak and frites, which also came with some whole slices of lettuce to remind me to eat my greens! We had some vino to pair and it was perfect. Only set back was giving me my steak medium when I asked for medium-rare.

hBIodYhwQZeoDSfUnNU3eQ.text: Just to preface, I live in France, so I've eaten a lot of French food and at brasseries. I'd probably give this 3.5 stars - the food is good, but not completely amazing, having been spoiled by all the French food in France.This place is huge, with a large dining room with wood panels, and ornate decor. It's quite pretty and the tables are nice with cloth napkins and wooden booths and tables. It's a good place for a business lunch or dinner. We went for lunch at 12:30 pm with a party of 3 and it was empty when we walked in, but the restaurant was full by 1 pm, so it's good to make a reservation ahead of time if you can.They have a wide selection of starters, entrees, sides and desserts - way more selection than you'd find a traditional brasserie. The complimentary bread is just okay, didn't seem particularly fresh to me - the texture was a bit too dense and wasn't quite as light or crunchy on the outside as I usually like.I got the salmon with a cream leek sauce which was good, but there's nothing except the fish with the dish - no potatoes or vegetables, it's just the piece of salmon in the sauce. If you want sides, you have to order them. In short, the salmon was good, the leek sauce was good, but a bit expensive for what you get with no sides for £17.75 for the dish.The fries we ordered as a side were a disappointment, they were soggy and cold. Definitely skip these - they weren't great.All in all, a good place for a business dinner or lunch if you're expensing your meal. It wasn't very "traditional" French or as good as food in France, but I didn't expect it to be. I thought it was a tad too expensive for what you get for the main dishes for them not to come with any kinds of sides. Just okay for me - I probably wouldn't come back on my own accord, but would eat here if someone else in my party really wanted to come here.

wWcoY_kfuJRQoOB8XmSPHg.text: My co wrkwrs raved about this place and recommended it. Came here with a group of 10 and ordered the 3 course meal. Was served a 2 course meal. They had forgotten about it. I mentioned it at the end, the person accommodating us didn't seem to care. Also was expecting a steak not just a ground beef patty as my entree. Ans the fries were a bit cold.  The carrot salad was very good though. Once the bill came 15% gratuity was added. You could really tell the servers attitude changed. He was already tipped and since then he was very unhelpful and unfriendly. Not sure if I'll be recommending this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Not sure. Steak but more like a ground beef patty.
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Carrot salad

QsMXVxUoYAkULNmKsIaNhg.text: Simply the best dinner experience ever. Going downstairs was like descending into my own Midnight in Paris dream...Midnight in London? dessert and wine were perfection and the waiters that helped us along the evening were sweet and very helpful. The whole atmosphere and music made for such an incredible night.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom

9ldwrgHqQlZ7cjJ3wCUzOA.text: Excellent all around! Ambiance, food, presentation, service, and price. The restaurant looks small from the outside but the dining area downstairs is enormous. The interior makes you feel like you are in France and has a very upscale look. This is only complemented by the service, which is the best I have seen in years! The escargot and chopped steak was delicious. The prices are unbelievably affordable. I would come here every time I visit London.

Lopcpne3i-Wy1yiXAx_sHg.text: What a great place - been here for a drink on the ground floor, but never ventured downstairs.  Magnificent venue, great menu...good prices, very reasonable, including 2 formules...though the wine is pricy - a great Saumur Champigny but £37.50 - ouchWe had endive & roquefort / œufs mayonnaise followed by whiting goujons / choucroute then coffeeThe choucroute was enough for 2 people and my companion thought it absolutely excellent all round; the goujons were ok but not stand out; the endives needed a tad more roquefort please, a bit stingy but very goodAll in all though a find for me; to return toBut...a French Brasserie would have had large glass of wine or a 50cls as options to soften the blow ... to consider

mhHZjgK806zDeK9qYd127Q.text: Despite being a French place, this is actually one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  It's on my short list of places I have to go to when I'm in London.  And I liked the atmosphere here more than any of the places I've been to in Paris.Brasserie Zédel has a few different parts to it.  Upstairs, there's a cafe.  Then walking downstairs, you get to the restaurant itself / dining room, a bar, and I think a theater.  I love the style of the building and the atmosphere.  It really feels like you're going back to a classier time.  The dining room is huge, and there's live music at times.I actually like having to wait for a table here...because it gives me an excuse to go to the cozy bar adjacent to the dining room downstairs.  Don't fill up too much on the popcorn though that they keep bringing out in the bar :)The food has been very good every time (I've usually gotten steak)...but the atmosphere for me is the most memorable aspect, and probably is the strongest pull for me to come back here.

vuXi_8G4gBofBiqNnPUiCA.text: I've avoided this place for the last 2 years simply because of its location, assuming it would be filled with boisterous tourists and tacky decor. To my surprise, it has become one of my favorite places, an all-in-one joint with a casual cafe at the top, and a cocktail bar and full restaurant underground. I adore the art deco theme, old posters and photographs of shows, musicians, and dancers covering the walls. Everything is elegant without being tacky. Head downstairs for a breathtaking view of balcony overlooking the crystal chandelier and tile floor. The staff are very kind and attentive, and continuously check in on you without being to helicopter-y. Cafe pricing is a bit high for a simple drink like fresh mint tea (2 pots of hot water with mint leaves and a few bite-sized pastries will set you back about £15) but the classy and quiet ambiance is worth it. There is also live music in the later evening without a cover charge, and in the heart of city center, it's a rare find.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Interior
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Stairwell
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Decor

ohzUjK8JjW5kyZ87NYqgEQ.text: Brasserie Zedel is a French style brasserie with a grand dining room decorated in a combination of the Beaux-arts and Art Deco styles. Descending the stairs from the small ground floor bar to the expansive room is quite an experience.The menu is reasonably priced for the location and there's a decent wine list, and  a vegetarian menu available on request, though it's not on the website.Food is decent rather than outstanding but is good value for the product very. On my recent visit, the starter of grated celeriac in mustard mayonnaise and the pudding of Ile Flottante were the highlights, though my main of artichokes in lemon sauce was a little bland. Bread and tap water arrived without asking. A bottle of Viognier was very pleasant and good value at £24.The total cost of two three course meals, wine and coffee, with service, came to just under £100. Service was a bit patchy as it was very busy, with lots of big groups. I suspect your experience will depend enormously on exactly where you sit.There's a cloakroom available and later in the evening a piano sets off the entertainment.So, it's great for an experience but not an intimate evening out.

photos.caption: Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Brasserie Zedel, main dining room
Photo of Brasserie Zedel - London, United Kingdom. Ile Flottante

2vec0TME9vcj7zEGYMjg4w.text: Beautiful dining roomHuge menuAttentive serviceP.S. Train your waiters to NOT get caught staring at a patrons tattoos. It's polite to comment, its not polite to stare 2 feet from the table!

sJcGLxh0tjHKd-2P8fNPzQ.text: Absolutely wonderful ambiance and place to eat. Service is fantastic. Food is generally pretty good, I usually have the steak (£8) and it's delicious. Friends who have other courses say they're pretty good, but I don't think the food is the best bit. Go for the great atmosphere and decent prices.

JrJznNKBFwtp_4NUKI06rw.text: Massively impressed with this place. We had passed it, looked in and thought we should give it a go some time. And so, last day of the boy's summer holiday, we popped in early lunch to see if we could get a table.First, the place is truly spectacular. It takes about 5 mins to get to the dining room from the street. As you descend down you pass wonderful old French posters and art works and it all has a very grand feeling as you pass a couple of receptions and a private bar. It's on the site of the old Atlantic bar and they haven't changed the layout much if that gives you an idea. The dining room is huge and noisy, bustling with customers and waiters dashing to serve them. The huge windows to the side give the impression of being outside but of course you are a long way underground. It's all great fun and there is a real good mix of people there, young old, snazzy, scruffy. The place has the feel of the old French brasseries. It has really pulled that off well. I loved the feeling.But that's not the best bit. Next the food.The menu is proper old French brasserie stuff. Confit duck, steak hache,    Charcuterie etc. A good few traditional starters to choose from, much less main courses. You are certainly not overwhelmed with choice.The boy had the set menu of two courses, starting with a carrot salad which was really lovely and simple. Julienned carrot tossed in vinegar and herbs and olive oil. I loved the simplicity. Tasted great. He followed with a simple burger, minus bun and perfectly cooked stiff fries. I had the grilled sardines. They came butterflied, three of them on a bed of black olives and cherry tomatoes. They were done perfectly again. Simply presented, well prepared with a slightly burnished skin as I think all oily fish should have. The missus had poached salmon which was poached perfectly. The accompanying cucumber and chive really set it off and the potato salad (which looked on presentation like it could have come from a can) was delicious.What I liked most was that there was no pretention. The food was bold and simply served. Nothing complicated, each dish standing out for what it was. This is such a refreshing change. Very brave when you consider they could have gone as overboard as with the surroundings.But that's not the best bit. The best bit is this. Check it out...The boy's set meal was £8. Yup. £8.My sardines were £9. And I think the salmon was £11.this to me represented unbelievable value. Not just for the food, but for the whole experience. All this with lovely chewy French loaf for the table. And slap bang in the middle of piccadilly. This is no tourist trap. This is just unbelievable value simple food in lush surroundings in the middle of London. On the starter menu you can get soup for under £3! Again, it's simple, nothing fancy, but all the better for it. But to think you can get that today in the heart of London at such a great place is frankly unbelievable and I applaud Corbin and king for what they have done here. Great stuff. I will be going back again and again.

S6XaaLNWbApPhMug0EpfjQ.text: Very different & quirky in a grandiose and powerfully French way. You step in and you think you're in the wrong place- a 1920s theatre, descending two or three flights of stairs you pass a private concert going on a bubbly bar, a 'ticket office' and finally arrive at the main dining area (all named in French). The dining room is expansive, alight with atmosphere with impressive bread sculptures that stood out along with the light marble walls & grand chandeliers. The good is very reasonable for tourist town, London. The service is all French and high standard. Highly impressive and would recommend to anyone, the only thing was we were cramped for space, they tried to get too many covers in the space they had. We could over hear both tables conversations next to us-not ideal! All in all, a great evening with a very different feel and warm surroundings.

GFl8_6X5KPdRB9oesv_CDw.text: exactly as per 3 stars...A-OK. its a great space, huge!, and the staff were all very polite and accommodating despite us being 20 mins late (waited at the bar for 10 mins before being seated). our waiter was a bit slack, had to be prompted on 2/3 occasions. food was decent, very parissienne and reasonably priced. basic however.£50 for a starter, 2 mains, 2 glasses of wine, 2 beers and 2 espressos.go check it out.

leH1n2N45bL-Wd80KwqctQ.text: Lovely looking venue.  Waited 90 minutes for a table for 2 with regular assurances we had not been forgotten.  Finally lost patience and walked out.

IHQDRPYkpJY_V64HDtCtFA.text: The setting is really beautiful.  Service was prompt and polite and did not complain when we asked whether we could be in and out within an hour so that we would not be late for the show to which we had tickets.  The food was good.  The Beef bourguignon was tasty, though slightly dry(a complaint I often have with slow-roasted beef; Todd English Pub is still the best I've had outside of mine or my sister's kitchens).  The escargot were good though too heavy on the garlic.  Onion soup was excellent and not over salted, which is unusual.  We'd return.

Y2b2kO-nZpVJjG9etPdwDg.text: Spectacular room, great atmosphere. Food was reasonably priced and pretty good: duck confit (the special for Monday) was very well prepared but the lamb couscous with merguez sausage was disappointing. The spice in the sausage obliterated the flavor of the meat while the lamb was too dry for any flavor to emerge. Dessert was pretty good. The real downer was the wait staff. I'll-informed, a bit snooty and over attentive. It was as if we were on an assembly line being hustled as quick as possible for the next round of guests.

Mko5JHPzp_LpGXJWrTtWIg.text: In the same week as my first visit I went to Zedel for a second time and it was actually even better. The service was faultless and the food even better. The chicken liver parfait is absolutely delicious, although fairly unremarkable in that it was no better than you would expect good parfait to be. But that suited me fine. The frogs legs were excellent, worth a visit to try these alone. For the main course I had steak hache which was very nice except they aren't allowed to serve it medium rare - i had to have medium which is not to my taste. Our waiter explained this is for health and safety reasons. Does anyone know why this would be the case when you can happily order steak tartare across London (not here though)?

Ddq5GfkvB7AKH8f5glRk6w.text: Through an unassuming quiet American bar leads to stairs down to a large old cinema room of rather belle epoque granduer filled with tables and noise drifts up to the high ceiling. Drinks at the bar while we wait for our table and its French brasserie service. I rather liked it, the prix fixe was reasonable, fresh and enjoyable, so was the wine. French Londoners at the next table made us feel we were in France. We worth a visit if near Piccadilly Circus.

PX5Uedx5gs-S0KPsEINvZQ.text: One of our best French meals turned out to be in London. This is an underground type of Restaurant that is huge, with super high ceilings. This place had a great atmosphere and a grande dining room feel. We had a late night dinner here. This was one of the best Venison meals ever! Falling off the fork tender. The service was good and the house wine was actually good. Very fair prices. The super long bar adds a nice touch.

SjzQAFFXIn2xbHUCETW5Ng.text: I can see why people like Zedel. Big dramatic room, Parisian brasserie atmosphere replicated. But what a dull menu! It's a complete pastiche with no novelty or inspiration. Why not nip over on the Eurostar if you want to eat like this? Still, decent service and satisfactory quality so it's not all bad. Just don't see the point of a place like this in London.

ZcvS7WPrgx8amummBCHbgA.text: Excellent value French brasserie right in the centre of Piccadilly. Huge basement room with grand finish gives a real sense of occasion and is truly breathtaking as you enter the room. Menu is well balanced though rarely changes. Prices are incredibly low. Cocktails are mixed well and the wine is reasonably priced and available by glass and carafe. Food is good to v good. Never excellent, never poor. Service is brisk and efficient though sometimes rather eastern european cold.

ABt-VaybvcWrq_7pIni7dg.text: I love Paris and french food!I went to Zedel last Tuesday and wasn't disappointed..French food,french venue..fortunately service wasn't french ;) (very polite and attentive). Very good prices too!

ViVsPEMXWFIsF_G60-tJOg.text: The food and service at Zedel are both absolutely outstanding, and I cannot recommend this West End brasserie highly enough. There's an excellent value set menu available at all times, and the standard menu is very well priced as well. I visited at lunchtime and the place was neither quiet nor busy, it was just about two-thirds full and the service we got was exceptionally good. The food came out in a timely fashion and was cooked perfectly, and we never felt rushed.Also worth a mention are the lovely toilets!

4MxtmP2mS5mf-P7M4bQBZw.text: It is a pitty that a restaurant with such a great interior and atmosphere serves such poor food.  The meat was dry and overcooked the Sauerkraut was booring and Not very well  spiced. The desstert was ok. But the capuccino was really  unswallowable. All in all it was obvious, that we were served food, which was  cooked hours ago and kept warm for hours.

bSbJBxFcfZKKenxuqXBsag.text: Right off Piccadilly Circus, Brasserie Zedel is a hidden gem of London! The decor and atmosphere is superb and the waiters are very friendly. Only slight let-down was the food, as it wasn't of the high-quality I was expecting. Overall, a very decent place for a night out with friends and family.

EyZk78nDkEnnzfkdPJ48YA.text: Having read an(other) entertaining review by Marina O'Loughlin  and loving French Brasserie food from working in France  I was looking forward to this being the first of a number of visits  but possibly not.7.0pm Saturday may not be the ideal time to try a restaurant for the first time  and I am greatful for being provided with a table instantly on arrival  but this is a slick operation and I feel should be capable of delivering far better than I received.The room is remarkable  and suggests far higher pricing than the menu offers.Booth seating by the bar (for 4) was smaller than comfortable for 3 adults  and those sitting at the bar often encroaching audibly and with their clothing and luggage across the table.Service a little slower than acceptable  which is understandable at a very busy time  but getting 3 out of 4 orders completely wrong is not.Not knowing what Bearnaise Sauce IS for a waiter in a Brasserie, let alone how to go about finding out  is a little perplexing. More troubling is being served a cold, yes cold, steak  and not the cut ordered.2 higher ranking service professionals did attend our table  and we had not actually complained in any negative way  one of whom seemed to think it would be beholden upon us to share her mission to inform management of what they have to deal with  rather than take affirmative action to improve our experience.Snark over  it was low priced for such a glamorous dining room in the heart of London  and while I feel a bit cheated  I may try again on a quieter day.

5RbSOcBjVPFaEJ-C19pNjw.text: When I was a young West Ender, a posh night out ended up in the familiar confines of Joe Allen. Slightly dirtier ones usually found you gurning round a four top in Balans or playing pinball up the rickety staircase of Bar Italia. You'd gone very wrong if you wound up in Shuttleworths... I was a little young for the Atlantic, that louche, debauched bacchanal under the old Regent Palace Hotel. It's to that space that we head tonight, now home to the newly launched Brasserie Zedel.It's not an expensive joint. And that's an understatement. Three courses for three people, coffee, wine and service clocked in at £90, phenomenal value given the quality. If this was a vanity project by new restaurateurs, you'd laugh at the prices and imaginging the rows with accountants, vowing to get as much grub down your neck as you could before they whacked the prices up. It's not though, it's the latest venture by two of the biggest restaurant thoroughbreds this country has produced, Chris Corbin and Jeremy King. If the brains behind The Wolesley and The Ivy think that this is the way the industry should price, prepare for the cutting of some prices or the sharpening of some knives...Bright, airy, tall and gilded. Even though you're in a basement, the whole experience is like being thrust into an Art Deco inspired cruise ship for the night. You could dress up to match if you want to but if you don't really want I can't see that anyone would mind. The menu reads like a 'Best of France - Bourgouis edition' cookbook from the 70's, in a really good way. Hefty, non sharing, mains are generally under a tenner, soups are less than three quid and other starters swirl the heady heights of a fiver. Substantial plated salads and big slabs of pâté are consumed with gusto while I chow down on escargot as garlically exotic as you remember from that first school trip to France as a 12 year old. Steak hache is made on site, a triumphantly large patty of the trimmings from proper cuts of beef, a tartare burger if you will. It was a little too solid in the construction but really well flavoured, coming with an inclusive metal cone of proper French fries (another pet hate of expensive places, the sides that should go with the dish should NOT be added chargable extras) and lashings of pepercorn sauce for £8.75.If the profiteroles were a tad over baked, it only served to highlight that these weren't perfectly pre-prepared, plumped generic pap but homemade and fresh from the subterranean bakery that had been responsible for an excellent (free) bread basket earlier. Arriving in London today, you couldn't ask for a better catch all recommendation than Zedel, it's there for groups of friends, good for serious foodies glomming at the novelty value, perfect for a classy date and suitable for clients and parents without any of them thinking you're skimping.I hate to end the review by keeping coming back to it, but i still can't understand why they're charging so little for this food. Sure it's what you'd expect to pay in a provincial French brasserie but this is a newly and expensively renovated spot on Picadilly Circus. They must really hate their accountant, or the rest of the industry...

4muNciLZeqYEn1MPfoOcjw.text: oh dear me! what a disappointment. a breathtaking entrance - old word glamour and the promise of great French food and loads of atmosphere. we know we'll have to wait for a table (we tried to book 2 days ago). we are told it'll be 45 minutes to an hour. we can wait at the bar. we make our way there, where we're offered a wine list. the first wine we order comes and it is a different vintage from the one advertised, I question it. I decline. they insist. we try it. the concensus is "no". we order a different bottle. again they bring us a younger vintage (is it me or is someone having a laugh here?). we are fobbed off with the explanation that the wines change in February. I explain that it's mid- February. we wait. we get a bottle of wine which is the grape and vintage on the wine list. oh thank goodness!we drink wine. we talk. we wait for our table. after 50 minutes we ask how the table is doing because it's now 9:35 and we are tired. small acknowledgement at the bar. I go back to the maitre'd. he says just another 10 minutes, "max!!" we wait another 20 minutes. we see quite a few empty tables that can seat four. we are a party of three.we are shown to a table. the band is playing. we are deposited under their noses. I can see three empty tables within a table-length of us, further from the volume of the brass section. we can hardly converse. the tables around us fill up. we order. we eat. it's good food. the clock is now ticking. would we like some dessert? one of us has to go home to Brighton. we explain that and ask for an espresso. no, they don't do an espresso. they do a cafetière. fine, lets have that. time passes. the Brightonian has to leave. we discuss the bill. she leaves. the coffee arrives - we explain its too late for three, but if we could please just have coffee for 2. "okay" they say, and whisk it away.we eat our dessert. it's delicious. we drink our single cafetière. we ask for the bill. we have been charged for an extra cafetière. and a discretionary 15% service charge. we don't pay that. we pay under a 10% tip and hope they'll get the message.ha! the place is almost full when we leave at 11pm. I don't think they'll get the message. we joke about how familiarly French it feels

zFKxtDerTdQtRho5eF1Scg.text: The service was good but a little sketchy as the hubby was complaining that the waitress had no idea of what kronenburg was.  The steak tartare is to be missed. The chicken roast was well executed. The place is the star. Really rococo and lively. Do have the chateau neff du pape. Great price for the bottle. Not sure if I will rush back, but all in all nice Sunday afternoon

a64YqKouLjilunCFevWuIQ.text: Fun place to meet friends but not conducive to intimate conversation. Very busy across lunchtime and on the face of it reasonably priced. Decor and atmosphere are its highlight, like a movie set from The Great Gadsby. Loved the Vichyssoise and amused to have it offered hot! Six of us had a good meal but not a great meal! Worth a visit if near Piccadilly.

Gko9HX2B1AX2Svx_mNNaWw.text: The secret is obviously out, so I figured I should add my own review.Two weeks ago after a theatre trip - the other half and I looking to have a nightcap decided to try the bar at Zedels. It was a Saturday night post 10pm, but when we walked in to the beautiful art deco Bar Americain it was virtually deserted. Quickly we were sat at a table, and a cocktail menu was bestowed upon us.Here's our rules on new cocktail bars.He will order an Old Fashioned - if it arrives too quickly, or is grainy - they fail.I will order a Manhattan - no one asks me how I want it - they fail.Do I get free snacks, I would also like some free snacks.And how did Bar Americain fare, well you know the answer, this is a 5 star review. Flying colours, a little dish of cashews preceded our perfectly made drinks. And then we got to thinking...the cocktails were perfectly made, they came with snacks, the room is beautiful - and they were under a tenner. It would be rude not to try something else. We got really drunk - it was great.This Wednesday I arranged to meet a friend there - and what a contrast. The bar was PACKED. The host found us the only spare table, but my secret was ruined...everyone was here. But what did I expect from such a great find. Like me anyone who had been there had decided to turn it into "their" bar.So after a cocktail or two we headed into the brasserie for dinner. Only a 20 minute wait for a table so we sat at the bar and had a very reasonable half bottle of chablis before being shown to our table. The food was incredible, we both ordered the same thing - grilled Daurade, with a side of green beans. Followed by a cheese plate and a mille feuille which we shared. Just like the bar, amazing value. Great food in a transformative setting - this place is grander than a duke and made us feel like ladies.If it wasn't already so popular I would have never shared this new find, but I urge you to try it. Go now.

ObWkVp4W_MXsVZVDgrWluw.text: I was prepared to be disappointed by Brasserie Zedel purely on the basis of my bigotry as a Londoner against anything within spitting distance of Piccadilly Circus. How wrong could I be? Turns out... enormously. To begin with, the Beaux-Arts/Art Deco interior of the old Atlantic  has been fastidiously preserved and the fittings gilded in a manner befitting a similar spree of gilt-edged pimping in 1980s Paris during the Mitterand-era. The effect of stepping off the street and descending underground in what actually feels a rather artificial entrance to the bars and restaurant adds to the experience of detachment from the real world and being spirited away to another land (... and time?).The service is French in the best way - well-trained career waiters who may appear detached, but are there whenever you need anything and always hover on the right side of professional and efficient. In fact on the first occasion I ate here, our waiter was straight out of central casting, an ethereal, almost corpse-like gentleman with a deeply sardonic wit and ability to know what we wanted before we'd asked.The food is brilliant, just what you'd want from a grand brasserie; andouillette, onglet, confit de canard and choucroutte are all present and correct, including those starters one seeks out of curiousity and novelty (cuisses de grenouille, escargots). The prices are frankly incredible, and can only be explained, I imagine, by the number of covers, table turnover and late opening hours. There is no sting lying in the drinks list either - Breton cider, 'pichets' of whites and reds (£6-£10) and well-priced bottles are available as well as own-brewed beers (the 'brasserie' moniker is merited) and crémants/champagnes.Food of this type and quality is available in bistros and brasseries around France, but there is no real reason to expect it outside of the country due to lack of competition, cultural and historical reasons and the ability to dress it up a little more and charge twice the price in London. The fact that you can walk in off the main tourist drag to have what is ostensibly a simple but high quality meal for pittance in W1 is rather incredible.Many an eloquent blogger and critic have waxed lyrical over the value for money of the overall Zédel experience, so let a simple, fawning francophile state the obvious one more time - you'll eat and drink very well in opulent surroundings and leave feeling like a thief when the bill is settled.

w1XiMmVboKXhovSGUf9A-w.text: Love it! First visit today and will definitely be back for more. Decor was amazing, food fabulous and service wonderful. Will test out the cocktail bar next time too- it looked rather impressive! I feel like I've just discovered a hidden London gem.

ZjWjvSsIsMvFMBV8CnSDDA.text: I LOVE.Don't do what we did and not make a reservation. This place was hopping even on a Wednesday. Take a step through the doors and take a step into Paris. The decor makes you feel like you truly have gotten on the Eurostar and into a Grand Brasserie in seconds. The food here is also absolutely spectacular. I had the Soup du Jour for starters which was a butternut squash soup which was amazing, and my dinner partner had a pate, which was also absolutely stunning. She had the Sea Bream for a main, which was done to perfection and I had the Onglet Grillee. The sauce was a tad bit too salty for my taste, but overall everything was done beautifully. We decided to indulge because it was my birthday and got two desserts. The profiteroles with chocolat chaud and the creme brulee. AMAZING. Including a bottle of wine, 3 separate courses and £78. Service was impeccable too. They didn't let me pour my own wine nor water and very attentive. It started to get less so when it got packed, but otherwise, definitely a go'er backer.I'm definitely headed back and a great place that's opened up in Soho for finer brasserie dining.

ooRYry320L6-fpSTEN9SsA.text: Fabulously pretty venue (rather blatantly styling itself after the Wolsey).Filled with unbelievably ugly badly dressed shoppers stumbling in from Regents street. With the odd pretty young thing mistakenly thinking this is stylish and up market.Food was rather more like the guests than the decor ... Service was sub cafe rouge ... Over all experience was cheap ... And slightly unsatisfactory ... Much like the coffee

5k6uxLEAbbGKsSbRstUWFg.text: Holy mother.  A friend took me here as a surprise, and it was amazing!  Upon walking in, a non-descript cafe, and then walking down several flights of marble stairs adorned by French posters, it opened into the Brasserie Zedel and American bar!  The Brasserie was fantastic - the decor is completely Art Deco and very well maintained, the service was top notch, and the food is not only affordable, but delicious as well.  We had some escargots (already out of the shell!), I had some duck confit (perfect!  And only 13.50!), and had the Ile Flottante and Baba de Rhum for dessert.  A perfect meal in a decadent location right out of a movie.  I will return!  Also: love the entertainment, so much atmopshere!

VDA44mJj3nOuvHPip2Necw.text: After scoring Book of Mormon tickets a couple hours before the show, I decided to grab dinner. Remembering a recent recommendation, I decided to try Brasserie Zedel. The space was far nicer than I anticipated. The staff were friendly, prices reasonable and food very tasty. For a really classy French dinner without breaking the bank, I highly recommend this place!

cLqeMKUpPi2HiA0aCn6E1A.text: The draw here is eating nice French style fare in a Parisian style brasserie that emulates a cross between famous real Gallic eateries such as La Coupole and Polidor in Paris and at the same time is the type of place where you could imagine Hemingway getting slowly sloshed in a corner....Foodwise it's honest and most dishes are a worthy choice. Being right in the heart of the West End (Piccadilly) it lends itself to a nice after dinner stroll along regent street as well.Good place...

9Y7h4SsmiNLTxFQUqPSgdg.text: This restaurant is the perfect setting for a first date. The venue is absolutely beautiful, set in an old Art Deco theatre dripping in Marble and Gold. The food was simple yet really delicious and the servings were the perfect side. They have a vey good selection of wines and there is definitely something on the menu to tickle everybody's fancy. Moderately priced, and not at all bad considering the venue and level of service received. We received complimentary aperitifs after dinner and had a great experience.

z8-P9anUC3TsgN_8hv_kvQ.text: Went there with a colleague and had dinner at the bar. Ambiance was great and prices reasonable for the location. The food was classic bistro with a number of provincial dishes. Would definitely go there again.

enVneQ_z4-CsBLQNwnKc6Q.text: After a pretty great first experience I had medium expectations of my second.  I knew the food wasn't great going into it, but thought the room and service would more than make up for any shortcomings.Well, after having eaten at Delaunay the other night, and at quite a few other beautiful restaurants in London in the past 2 weeks I am no longer so impressed by aesthetics alone, and realize they only act as a bolster to a good experience rather than a positive attribute in their own right.Service this time was absolutely crap.  Our server was beyond clueless, didn't know the menu, and had to be flagged down at every interaction.  He could not even clear the plates properly; he leaned over us and made an absolute racket which was really quite annoying.  When we wanted to leave, we waited forever for the bill, and then we asked for the card machine, he was mid-conversation (def not work related) with another server and ignored us, grabbed the machine, went back to conversation, and then finally came back to us after my having to interrupt him a 2nd time.I thought the food was a 2/10 -- edible, but just (deserts were fine though). My celeriac remoulade tasted like it was doused in fish stock, my beetroot and lettuce salad had 4 miniscule slices of beets, and the lettuce wasn't cleaned properly as I bit into some rocky piece.  My main, the plaice, was fairly good on one side (firm and slightly crisp), but when flipped to the other the fish was very soft, and the skin/coating was a gloopy mess.  My parents both had the same problem with their fish as well.My sis had a rib-eye steak which was tough and flavourless, my wife had a hanger steak which was better meat, but almost inediblely rare and came covered with a acrid onion sauce. Our side of creamed spinach looked and tasted like baby food, and the fries were not 1/2 as good as McDonalds (crispy-ish but had a very dense bite).Desert and drinks, however, were good.,After such an awful experience I am even doubting whether I even like the room -- yes its obviously lavish, but is cavernous, and underground.  We were considering removing the service charge (something I've maybe done once in my life), but we simply couldn't bother having to deal with the fallout.Would never go again, and am dreading my dinner at Colbert next week (can't get out of it im afraid).

rkWm7bj9UC4OD40mWy2cZw.text: Really lovely restaurant, lovely ambience with a live band playing French music. Food was delicious, service a little slow. Reasonably priced for such a lovely place too.

ohB8lTPfqqezoGthwd0nRw.text: The place is reallyremarkable and having a great atmosphere. The food is pretty good and deliciousat very reasonable price. They use high quality meat and it is truly juicy and delicious.Theplace has a nice atmosphere with high ceilings and elegant style. They alsooffer mouth-watering desserts.The service is very good, and the staffs are veryattentive and friendly. It is a perfect place for a date and even meetings.

OGN78QZAcGVkklCYdZISqA.text: You start your Brasserie Zedel experience in a ground-level tabac-styled room and then descend a chintzy jazz portrait-lined staircase to the basement hallway. From there, you have three options: a room dedicated to cabaret (tonight's entertainment was a transvestite jazz singer not dissimilar looking to Jim Henson's Miss Piggy), the low-lit and swanky looking American Bar and the main dining room. We only visited the latter. The main dining room is an incredible space, reminiscent of Paris institutions like La Coupole and Bofinger. It's covered in gold leaf, marble and looks absolutely the part, much more convincing that the entry halls which look more Las Vegas than Paris. Our waiter was a little slow in first arriving, but attentive and professional throughout the meal. A complimentary basket of bread was brought up. I ordered the onion soup to start, my partner ordered the oysters. The onion soup was good, although hardly much of an achievement to do a good French onion soup. Could've done with some more cheese. Her Oysters were very nice, and pretty reasonable. For mains I opted for the Choucroute Alsacienne, and she had the  Beef Bourguignon. Again, mine was a simple dish that didn't really blow me away, although you might wonder if this dish is really capable of being that amazing anything. It did the job, adequately. Her beef was a little tough and chewy, the accompanying mash good. For desert we shared the Gateau Opera, which was delicious. We both opted for the house red, pretty reasonably priced and quite tasty, although I'm no expert. Let's be honest, this place is trying to offer a Parisienne Brasserie experience in London's West End, and it does that, to an extent, only perhaps in the same way that the Venezio hotel offers you a little Venice amidst Las Vegas' strip. This is not to say it wasn't enjoyable; it was, it just isn't really anything mind-blowing. Its solid takes on French staples aren't going to offer any serious competition for a good Parisienne brasserie, but if you want a decent taste of France in a beautiful, opulent venue for not a great deal of money, you'll probably enjoy it.

vyqf7C4v-dan5MQ449S-Dg.text: Loved the Art Deco setting. Spectacular. It is worth a trip for the setting alone. Some of the dishes were rather bland though.

UxzamcESmxF8bNKVdgjSTg.text: One of my favourite restraurants in London. Looks like a Parisian brasserie. Food is not too expensive and served in art deco surroundings. I always got brilliant service but booking a table is recommended.
